claims_to_validate.claim_text: The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.

The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the formula configured in leave policy for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not actively used. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate gratuity amount. When calculating End of Service (EOS) gratuity, the system fails to recognize 2024 as a leap year, causing a calculation discrepancy of approximately AED 17.26.

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.
System gratuity calculation (AED 231,821) differs from manual calculation (AED 252,485), with support explaining the system calculation follows a specific service duration and daily wage formula

The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently account for February 29th in leap years, causing a minor discrepancy in total service days calculation (912 vs 913 days). The difference impacts the final gratuity amount calculation.

Platform calculates total job tenure with a potential extra day (623 days instead of 622 days), causing slight variations in gratuity calculations. The discrepancy stems from how working days are counted and converted to years.

System calculates leave salary using a fixed daily rate divisor (potentially 30 days) which may not accurately reflect calendar month variations. User expected calculation based on 31 days, but system used a different configuration.

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using different daily wage divisors (30 vs 30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days, leading to different prorated amounts.

User misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The daily wage calculator fails to correctly prorate salary when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. The system only correctly prorates salaries when departure dates are in the past.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

Public holiday additions after leave request creation cause mismatches between HR and Payroll systems' daily wage calculations, resulting in incorrect salary deductions. The Time Off module does not send complete leave request details to the Payroll module at the time of calculation, causing data inconsistency when configuration changes occur mid-cycle.

The system displays incorrect number of days (31 instead of 29) in remarks for February unpaid leave deduction, despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct. This is a display bug in the remarks field where the wrong number of days is referenced.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual leave policy calculations, potentially causing incorrect salary deductions by using gross salary instead of basic salary.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate is inconsistent with the leave period.
Salary is calculated based on a standard of 26 working days per month, derived from 365 annual days minus 52 weekly offs, resulting in 313 working days divided by 12 months.

Payroll daily wage calculator configuration overrides leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations. The leave policy formula becomes non-editable (greyed out) when payroll settings are configured.
Leave deduction calculations are dependent on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.
System defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize leap years in service period calculations.
Pro-rated amount calculations consistently produce results that are 0.1 or 0.2 less than expected, affecting all employees' End of Service calculations.
Leave days are only accrued at the end of the month, preventing prorated accrual for mid-month departures
Unclear rules for counting service days, including whether departure date is considered a working day and how leap year days are handled

The platform's leave salary calculation follows predefined policy configurations that cannot be easily overridden for specific scenarios.
